div.p: This subtag is located in BIOGRAPHY PERSONNAME . It captures titles of nobility, sometimes more than one held successively, by a woman in right of her husband or less commonly of herself. It has attributes for REG (use for variant spelling) and WROTEORPUBLISHEDAS (use Yes or leave blank).Ranks are duchess, marchioness, countess, viscountess, Lady, and Dame. (Lady is confusing; it’s the correct title of a baron’s or baronet’s or knight’s wife, but also a kind of abbreviation or familiar form of everything else below a duchess). Many sources confuse TITLED with STYLED, but even in this matter we can aim at accuracy. Titled within PERSONNAME should record titles borne by a writer, even if we choose her first and last names as the Standard. When in doubt ask advice.

div.codeblock:
Lady Barnard Baroness of Cramond

EC was given a title nominally in her own right in 1628 because her husband was barred from the award, being a judge.

div.p: See STYLED for difference between peers and peeresses (Titled) and their children (Styled). Include complete titled name in element and not just name of title: Baroness Abergavenny, not just Baroness. Dame Mary Bloggs has been granted her title as an honour; Mary, Lady Bloggs has married a man with a title.
